trial_identification.studytitle: Efficacy of ultrasound guided Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) block following major abdominal surgery: a randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: women undergo elective caesarean section-Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) block on the abdominal wall under ultrasound guidance-conventional postoperative analgesic management-reduce pain medications post operation and improve patient comfort

conditions.healthcondition: healthy women undergo elective caesarean section, no allergy to the analgesic drug ropivacaine and morphine.

interventions.interventions: Intervention: patient receive ropivacaine 200mg by the TAP block technique. All patients will be treated with standardised pain management and post analgesic care after surgery including a Patient Controlled Analgesia (PCA) device which will deliver standard doses of morphine (1mg with a 5 minute lockout) intravenously when patient requires it for pain relief.
interventions.comparator: Control: patients receive injection of normal saline by the TAP block technique.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Other pain medications and patient satisfaction

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Emergency caesarean section, refusal to participate in the study, allergies to any of the drugs used in the study (e.g. morphine or ropivacaine); insufficiency in speaking or reading English.

trial_design.concealment: Randomisation slips will be stored in numbered opaque sealed envelopes and opened only in consented patients prior to surgery
trial_design.sequence: Sequence will be computer generated in blocks.
trial_design.designfeatures: Patients will be blinded from what injection they receive. Only the anaesthetist who performed the procedure knows what the patient received, others including an observer will be blinded and responsible for monitoring patients progress and pain treatment requirements. The data analyst will also be blinded.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Department of Anaesthesia, St Vincent's Hospital

fundingsource.fundingname: Department of Anaesthesia, St Vincent's Hospital

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Dr Michael Barrington, St Vincent's Hospital

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The object of this project is to determine how useful an ultrasound guided TAP block is in reducing requirement for pain medications following elective caesarean section.

contact.name: Dr Michael Barrington
contact.address: c/o Department of Anaesthesia St Vincents Hospital Melbourne Fitzroy VIC 3065
